    Nazanin Boniadi takes aim at UN for letting Iran ‘legitimise itself’
    British-Iranian actress Nazanin Boniadi has taken aim at the United Nations for enabling the Islamic Republic of Iran to use the organisation to “legitimise itself”. Ms Boniadi sat down with Sky News Australia host Laura Jayes to discuss the dangerous regime of the Islamic Republic of Iran. Ms Boniadi urged the West to enforce sanctions on Iranian officials amid the rampant human rights abuses in the country. She said the Islamic Republic is using the United Nations to “normalise” itself to the global public. “The problem with the UN is … when UN member states and their representatives don’t stand for democracy, and they play into the Islamic Republic’s propaganda and side with them, then we’re never going to see change,” she told Sky News Australia.

The CTBT, adopted in 1996, bans nuclear explosions globally but has not been fully implemented. The offshore quake was at a depth of 19.2 km (12 miles), USGS said, off the central province of Eastern Samar. The Philippine Institute of Volcanology and Seismology warned of damage and aftershocks in an advisory but there were no immediate reports of casualties.     A mob in a small town in Senegal dug up the body of a man suspected of being gay, dragged his body through the streets and then burned it during the night of October 28, 2023. While there have been other instances of exhumations of people suspected of being gay, the incident that took place in Kaolack, a town 200 kilometres southeast of Dakar, is different because it was filmed and posted online, says our Observer, a member of a group dedicated to upholding the human rights of LGBT Africans.  ( 29 min )

Since then, the security situation in Africa’s Sahel region has continually worsened. Today, the vast area stretching from Mauritania to Sudan has become a no man's land for journalists, a black hole for news.  ( 27 min )

The phenomenon, according to one psychologist, comes down to people finding ways to cope with the “unbearable uncertainty” clouding the country’s future.  ( 25 min )

    'Pathetic': Marjorie Taylor Greene attacks 'feckless Republicans' who voted against her
    She tried to censure and it came up short. Now she's shaming the names who didn't vote in favor. Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene (R-GA) had willed a resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib (D-MI) for her attendance of a protest opposing the war in Gaza. POLL: Should Trump be allowed to run for office? "List of feckless Republicans that voted WITH Democrats to table my censure resolution against Rashida Tlaib," Greene said on Wednesday. "This is why Republicans NEVER do anything to stop the communists Democrats or ever hold anyone accountable!! PATHETIC." She created a social media thread naming some of her friends in the House who didn't have what it took to vote with her. They include current House Speaker Mike Johnson, Rep. Chip Roy (R-TX), and Rep. Ken Buck (R-CO) who announced he wasn't running for reelection. Earlier in the week, Greene preemptively lashed out after learning that her effort wasn't gaining a coalition in Congress. "I want to remind you, this happened on the same day Hezbollah declared a day of immense anger," she said. "And Rashida Tlaib organized with that group. And they did. They did protest, and they did an insurrection into our Capitol complex, stopping Congress and stopping the Senate." The media was quick to take notice of the lawmaker's swing and miss Wednesday. "Colleague Kelly Phares rpts 23 GOPers join Dems to table or kill effort to censure Dem MI Rep Tlaib," tweeted Chat Pergram. Melanie Zanona also tweeted: "motion to table — aka kill — MTG’s resolution to censure Rep. Rashida Tlaib just passed the House, with help of 23 Republicans." MTG offered the resolution."  ( 43 min )

  • Open

    Gaza's southern border crossing opens to evacuate some stranded foreign nationals
    Gaza's southern border with Egypt was opened Wednesday for the first time since the Israel-Hamas war broke out on Oct. 7, to allow about 500 foreign nationals to evacuate Gaza and allow some critically-injured Palestinians to get medical treatment in Egypt. Diplomatic sources told CBS News that the evacuations were negotiated by the U.S. and Qatar. Charlie D'Agata has the latest.  ( 14 min )
    White House calls Gaza evacuations "an important breakthrough"
    A State Department spokesperson on Wednesday hailed the evacuation of hundreds of stranded foreign nationals, including U.S. citizens, from war-stricken Gaza as an "important breakthrough," with the Biden administration hoping that further evacuations will continue in the coming weeks. Nancy Cordes has more.  ( 13 min )
    "CBS Evening News" headlines for Wednesday, November 1, 2023
    Here's a look at the top stories making headlines on the "CBS Evening News with Norah O'Donnell."  ( 14 min )
    Hamas alleges second Israeli strike hit refugee camp, hostages among dead
    Hamas has claimed that seven hostages taken from its Oct. 7 attacks inside Israel, including three foreign passport holders, were killed in Israel's first bombing of Gaza's largest refugee camp on Tuesday.  ( 6 min )
    Authorities investigating Star of David symbols spray-painted on Paris buildings
    Prosecutors in France have opened an investigation after blue Star of David symbols were found spray-painted on several buildings in Paris.  ( 6 min )
    Surfer's body missing after reported attack by large shark off Australia
    One man said it was a great white shark. Another said he "saw him in the wave and the shark had his body in his mouth -- it was pretty gruesome."  ( 7 min )
    10/31: CBS Evening News
    Dozens killed in Israeli airstrike on Gaza refugee camp; Dozens evacuated after Disney World monorail gets stuck  ( 23 min )
    FBI director warns that Hamas attack could inspire terrorism on U.S. soil
    FBI Director Christopher Wray told Congress Tuesday that the attack by Hamas militants on Israel could inspire domestic extremist groups to plan similar attacks in the U.S. targeting Jewish or Muslim communities. Scott MacFarlane has more.  ( 14 min )
    Israeli airstrikes target Hamas in Jabaliya refugee camp in Gaza
    Israel carried out airstrikes and ground operations in the Jabaliya refugee camp in northern Gaza, targeting what it called a Hamas "terrorist stronghold." Palestinian officials said civilians were killed.  ( 6 min )

  • Open

    Pakistan: Six terrorists killed in Balochistan's Zhob
    Six terrorists were killed during an operation in the Sambaza area of Balochistan's Zhob district. Security forces conducted the operation based on intelligence reports. The Inter-Services Public Relations (ISPR) stated that the terrorists were involved in activities against security forces and targeting innocent civilians. A cache of arms, ammunition, and explosives was also recovered. The area is being sanitized to eliminate other militants. Pakistan has witnessed an increase in terrorism, particularly in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa and Balochistan.  ( 46 min )
    Biden and the first lady will travel to Maine to mourn with the community after the mass shooting
    President Joe Biden will visit the community of Lewiston, Maine, to mourn the victims of the deadliest mass shooting in the state's history. The shooting took place on October 25, resulting in 18 deaths and 13 injuries. Biden and First Lady Jill Biden will pay their respects to the victims, meet with first responders, and grieve with the community. The alleged gunman, Robert Card, was found dead of an apparent suicide after a manhunt. Investigators are focusing on Card's mental health as a possible motive.  ( 47 min )
    Donald Trump Jr testifies he never worked on the key documents in his father's civil fraud trial
    Donald Trump Jr testified in a civil fraud trial that he never worked on his father's financial statements, which are at the center of the trial. The lawsuit alleges that the former president and his business misled banks and insurers by inflating his net worth on the statements. Trump Jr said he signed off on the statements as a trustee but left the work to outside accountants. Eric Trump is also expected to testify in the trial, followed by the former president himself. The trial is in its second month and is being closely watched.  ( 70 min )
    Uganda court fines US couple $28,000 for 'inhumane treatment' of their foster child
    A US couple has been fined $28,000 by a court in Uganda after pleading guilty to child cruelty and "inhumane treatment" of their 10-year-old foster child. The couple admitted to making the child sleep on a wooden platform and feeding him cold food. They were sentenced to two months in prison, which they have already served, and ordered to pay the victim $26,000 in compensation. The case has sparked criticism from child rights activists in Uganda, who have called it a travesty of justice.  ( 47 min )
    For China's jobless young people, hostels are the place to be
    Hostels in China have become refuges for young people struggling to find jobs in major cities. As joblessness among young Chinese reaches record highs, hostels provide a place for individuals to stay between interviews and strategize for their next networking meeting. The hypercompetitive nature of China's white-collar job market, combined with a slowing economy, has made it increasingly difficult for young people to secure well-paying jobs. Even those who have found employment often struggle to afford housing. The situation has worsened in recent years, with fewer job offers available.  ( 50 min )
    US man who beat Sikh man to death faces hate charge
    A Sikh man was killed by an American, after a minor car crash in October, was motivated by "rage inflamed by hate," the Queens district attorney said. The accused Gilbert Augustin following the crash repeatedly beat the victim, Jasmer Singh and called him "turban man." The new charges filed against him Tuesday included manslaughter and assault as hate crimes. Augustin faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted.  ( 41 min )
    China sends 43 aircraft, 7 ships close to Taiwan
    At least 43 military aircraft and seven ships China sent to Taiwan, a latest sign that Beijing plans no let-up in its campaign of harassment, threats and intimidation. Taiwan's defence ministry said 37 of the aircraft had crossed the median line in the Taiwan Strait, which China no longer recognises as an informal divider between the sides.  ( 43 min )
    29-year-old Indian student stabbed at gym in US, critical
    A 29-year-old student from Telangana, India, named Putcha Varun Raj, was stabbed in the head by a man at a gym in Indiana, United States. The attacker, Jordan Andrade, claimed that he found Varun "a little weird" and felt threatened by him. Varun, who was pursuing his MS in computer science, had a slim chance of survival due to the severity of his injuries. Varun's family has requested assistance from the government, and the Indian embassy and NRIs from Telangana have pledged their support.  ( 47 min )
    New details emerge after Matthew Perry's autopsy, cause of death 'deferred'
    Actor Matthew Perry was found unresponsive and not breathing in his hot tub at his California residence. The Los Angeles Fire Department arrived at the scene but Perry was already deceased. An autopsy has been completed, but the cause of death has been deferred pending further tests. Foul play is not suspected at this time. Perry was best known for his role as Chandler Bing on the sitcom "Friends," and his co-stars have expressed their grief over his loss.  ( 50 min )
    US commandos on the ground in Israel helping to locate hostages
    American commandos are assisting Israel in locating and rescuing the hostages taken during Hamas' cross-border attacks. The US Special Operations forces are working alongside FBI and state department experts to coordinate efforts with Israeli counterparts. While the commandos are not assigned combat roles, they are advising on the complexities of a potential ground invasion of Gaza. The US forces in the region are also prepared to assist American citizens and secure embassies if needed. The exact number of commandos deployed has not been disclosed.  ( 45 min )
    Jordan, a key ally of US, recalls its envoy from Israel
    Jordan, a key US ally, said Wednesday it has recalled its ambassador from Israel and told Israel's ambassador to remain out of the country in protest over the "humanitarian catastrophe" in Gaza. Jordan's deputy PM said the return of the ambassadors is linked to Israel "stopping its war on Gaza ... and the humanitarian catastrophe it is causing." Jordan signed a peace deal with Israel in 1994. Meanwhile, Bolivia said on Tuesday it had broken diplomatic ties with Israel  ( 41 min )
    28 countries and EU sign pact against AI's 'catastrophic' risks
    Countries such as India, UK, US, and China have agreed to collaborate in order to protect against the potential harm caused by artificial intelligence (AI). This agreement was reached at the world's first summit on AI safety, held in Bletchley Park, UK. The participating nations signed the "Bletchley Declaration," emphasizing the need to collectively manage the risks associated with AI. While the declaration lacks specific policy goals, a second meeting is scheduled in South Korea and a third in France.  ( 47 min )
    PIO soldier among 16 Israelis killed in a battle inside Gaza
    An Indian-origin Israeli soldier was killed while fighting against Hamas in Gaza. Staff-Sgt. Halel Solomon, 20, was from the southern Israeli town of Dimona. Dimona’s mayor, Benny Bitton took his Facebook and said, ​​“It is with great sorrow and grief that we announce the death of a son of Dimona, Halel Solomon, in the battle in Gaza."  ( 40 min )
    Israel puts missile boats in Red Sea as Houthis attack from Yemen
    The Israeli military said it had deployed missile boats in the Red Sea on Wednesday as reinforcements, a day after the Iran-aligned Houthi movement said it had launched missile and drone attacks on Israel and vowed to carry out more. Images disseminated by the military showed Saar-class corvettes patrolling near Eilat port in the Red Sea, which Israel sees as a new front as its war in Gaza draws retaliation from Iran-aligned pro-Hamas forces elsewhere in the region  ( 41 min )
    First evacuees exit Gaza as refugee camp struck again
    At least 320 foreign passport holders and injured Gazans were evacuated from the Palestinian enclave through the Rafah crossing into Egypt on Wednesday, under a deal mediated by Qatar. Initially, 500 foreign passport holders were expected to be allowed out of Gaza in the coming days. Talks are ongoing for further evacuations, with the US aiming to evacuate 400 Americans. The limited evacuations come after more than three weeks of a total blockade of Gaza by Israel, following an attack by Hamas fighters. Hospitals in Gaza are also facing a critical shortage of fuel.  ( 51 min )
    Cornell student held for threats to Jews
    Patrick Dai, who has been accused of making violent threats against Jewish students, was arrested. He called for the deaths of Jewish people and said he was ‘gonna shoot up 104 west.'  ( 39 min )
    US Federal Reserve keeps interest rates at 22-year high
    The US Federal Reserve has decided to maintain interest rates at a 22-year high for the second consecutive meeting in an effort to control inflation without harming the strong economy. The Fed aims to cool down demand and encourage companies to slow down price increases. Despite the economy's resilience, inflation has gradually decreased from its peak in 2022. The Fed is focused on bringing inflation back in line with its 2% target and is considering whether to implement one final rate increase in the coming months.  ( 54 min )
    Italy PM Giorgia Meloni talks of Ukraine fatigue, migration in prank call
    Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni expressed international fatigue with the conflict in Ukraine and a lack of support for Italy in dealing with migration in a phone call with Russian pranksters. The 13-minute audio of the call, released by the pranksters, revealed Meloni's frustration with the situation. She also criticized the belief that Italy should solve the migration problem alone. The pranksters praised Meloni for sharing her genuine opinions, unlike other European politicians who act like programmed robots.  ( 47 min )
    Israel Hits Hamas Hub In Dense Gaza
    An Israeli strike in Gaza caused extensive damage and casualties in a densely populated neighborhood. The Gaza health ministry claimed that hundreds of people were killed and injured, although this could not be immediately verified. Israel stated that the strike targeted Hamas militants, including a commander responsible for a previous massacre. Israeli ground troops and tanks are advancing further into Gaza, while humanitarian officials warn of a growing catastrophe for Palestinian civilians.  ( 51 min )

    There Are Currently 40,000 U.S. Ground Troops In The Middle East
    Axios: Where U.S. troops are stationed in the Middle East  With the Israel-Hamas war escalating, the United States risks becoming involved in a larger conflict that could entangle some of the more than 40,000 U.S. military personnel based across the region.   Why it matters: U.S. troops and military contractors in Iraq and Syria have been targeted in over a dozen attacks by Iranian-backed militia groups since Hamas' surprise attack against Israeli civilians and soldiers on Oct. 7.   * Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin has warned of the "prospect of a significant escalation of attacks on our troops and our people throughout the region."   * Between the lines: The attacks, as well as a wider war, could reverse efforts in recent years to reduce the U.S. presence in the Middle East as part of a strategic pivot to toward the Pacific.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: More U.S. troops are being deployed ....     Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia
    Saudi Arabia Eurofighter Typhoon – Wikipedia   EruAsian Times: French Rafales ‘Trounce’ Eurofighters As Germany Blocks Sale Of Typhoon Jets To Saudi Arabia – Reports   Germany loosened export restrictions against Saudi Arabia earlier this year. Still, it refused to allow the sale of the 4.5th generation Eurofighter Typhoon fighter jet to the kingdom, despite the UK government’s intense lobbying. Berlin’s refusal, unfortunately, poses a significant challenge to Britain’s production lines.  The United Kingdom is likely to see a loss of 6,000 jobs in the defense sector and no manufacturing of fighter jets for a decade in the face of Germany’s unwillingness to green-light the sale of Eurofighter Typhoon jets to the Royal Saudi Air Force, British newspaper The Sun reported. Berlin is blocking a multibillion-dollar agreement to sell 48 Typhoons to Saudi Arabia, and ministers have threatened to “close” BAE production lines if the contract is refused. German Chancellor Olaf Scholz clarified in July this year that Germany will not deliver Eurofighter combat aircraft to Saudi Arabia soon.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: The impact on the UK for losing this sale is going to be huge ....     North Korea Closes A Dozen Embassies Around The World
    Reuters: North Korea closes multiple embassies around the world   North Korea is poised to close as many as a dozen embassies including in Spain, Hong Kong, and multiple countries in Africa, according to media reports and analysts, in a move that could see nearly 25 percent of Pyongyang's missions close worldwide.  North Korea's recent closing of its diplomatic missions was a sign that the reclusive country is struggling to make money overseas because of international sanctions, South Korea's unification ministry said on Tuesday.  On Monday, North Korean state media outlet KCNA said the country's ambassadors paid "farewell" visits to Angolan and Ugandan leaders last week, and local media in both African countries reported the shutdown of the North's embassies there.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: Running an embassy or any other diplomatic office is not cheap.     Violence Is Surging In The West Bank
    Al-Monitor: West Bank death toll exceeds 120 as US warns Israel over settler violence  Over 120 Palestinians in the West Bank have been killed amid raids by the Israeli army and settler attacks since Oct. 7.  As Israel expands its ground incursion in the Gaza Strip, violence in the West Bank is also escalating, with at least 115 Palestinians killed and more than 2,000 injured since the Israel-Hamas war started on Oct. 7, according to the United Nations.  Clashes between Palestinians in the West Bank and the Israel Defense Forces as well as attacks by Jewish settlers are common, but both have intensified in recent weeks.  The IDF has been conducting an increasing number of raids in the West Bank since the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on southern Israel killed 1,400 Israelis, mostly civilians.     Yemen's Houthis Have Officially Waded Into The Israel-Hamas War
    The Long War Journal: Houthis launch third strike against Israel, threaten more attacks  The Israel Defense Forces intercepted a missile and two drones over the Red Sea that were fired by Ansar Allah, the Iran-backed group in Yemen more commonly known as the Houthis, earlier today. The attack marked the third by the Houthis that has targeted Israel, and the terror group has threatened more as Israel pushes its ground offensive into Gaza.  The missiles and two drones were launched from the “Red Sea area” and shot down “outside the territory of the State of Israel,” the IDF said, according to The Times of Israel. The Houthi missile was shot down with the Arrow air defense system, while Israel Air Force fighters downed the two Houthi drones.     Politico: ‘Putin will be successful’ if lawmakers cut Ukraine funding, top leaders warn  Senators mostly agree, setting up a showdown with the House.  Top Biden administration officials warned senators on Tuesday that if they approve aid to Israel but cut out funding for Ukraine, Vladimir Putin will win.  Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin argued against decoupling President Joe Biden’s $106 billion supplemental request for Israel, Ukraine and the Pacific while testifying before the Senate Appropriations Committee.  The pair warned Russia would prevail without continued U.S. assistance and would have implications outside of Europe.   Read more ....  U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin Say Russia Will Win If Ukraine Aid Is Cut   Top US officials make case for Ukraine aid -- France 24   Russia will succeed in Ukraine unless US support continues-Pentagon chief -- Reuters   Putin will win if Israel funding split from Ukraine, Blinken and Austin tell senators -- The Hill
    Mass Exodus Of Afghans Begin As Deadline To Leave Pakistan Arrives
    FOX News: Pakistan set to deport over 1.4 million undocumented Afghan nationals; UN seeks relief on deadline   Pakistan’s government announced a major crackdown earlier this month  Pakistan's government plans to deport over 1.4 million Afghan nationals after November 1, and the United Nations is calling for the country to hold off to avoid human rights violations.  The Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights (OHCHR) said in a press release that it is "extremely alarmed" by Pakistan’s deportation announcement, as there are currently over two million undocumented Afghans living in the country.  Of the two million, more than 600,000 are immigrants who left Afghanistan after the Taliban reclaimed power in August 2021.   Read more ....  Mass Exodus Of Afghans Begin As Deadline To Leave Pakistan Arrives  Afghans make up majority of 140000 leaving Pakistan as deadline set to expire -- Reuters   Mass exodus of Afghans as deadline to leave Pakistan arrives -- AFP   Thousands of Afghans forced to return as Pakistan’s anti-migrant deadline ends -- The Independent   Afghan refugees forced to leave Pakistan say they have nothing -- BBC
    White House Says Biden Will Meet With China’s Xi Jinping Next Month At The APEC Summit In San Francisco
    CNBC: Biden will meet with China’s Xi Jinping next month, White House says  * President Joe Biden will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month.   * The meeting will take place on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, summit in San Francisco.  WASHINGTON — President Joe Biden will meet with Chinese President Xi Jinping next month, the White House announced on Tuesday.  The leaders of the world’s two largest economies are expected to meet on the sidelines of the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation, or APEC, summit in San Francisco.  “Intense competition means intense diplomacy,” White House press secretary Karine Jean-Pierre said at a press briefing. “Our policy and how we move forward with China has not changed.”  Jean-Pierre declined to provide details about Biden’s agenda other than he is expected to have “a tough conversation” with Xi.   Read more ....  White House Says Biden Will Meet With China’s Xi Jinping Next Month At The APEC Summit In San Francisco   Biden and Xi to meet in San Francisco in November, White House says -- CBS   Biden expected to meet with Xi Jinping next month for ‘constructive’ talks -- The Guardian/AFP   Biden will meet China's Xi next month: White House confirms talks just two days after Beijing's top army general warned he would show 'no mercy' to any nation backing Taiwan -- Daily Mail

    No, this video doesn’t show a Palestinian pretending to be injured in the Israel-Hamas war
    Some pro-Israeli social media users are claiming that Palestinians are posting videos pretending to be injured by the bombing campaign carried out by Israel since October 7. On October 26, for example, pro-Israeli accounts started sharing claims that a Palestinian video maker had pretended to be injured. Their so-called proof was two videos – one said to show the man in a hospital bed and the next one, apparently filmed the next day, showing him in perfect health. It turns out, however, that the video of the injured man is from August 2023, months before the war broke out. Moreover, it shows another man – and a real victim of the ongoing conflict.  ( 30 min )

    Thousands of Afghans leave Pakistan ahead of deportation deadline
    Hundreds of thousands of undocumented Afghans living in Pakistan now face arrest and deportation after the government's deadline for them to leave voluntarily expired this Wednesday, November 1. Pakistan's interior minister justified his decision, taken in early October, by the number of Afghans involved in recent terror attacks in Pakistan. Some 200,000 Afghans have already left Pakistan voluntarily – albeit often reluctantly – ahead of the November 1 deadline. Our correspondents Shahzaib Wahlah and Sonia Ghezali report.  ( 27 min )

    ‘God help if you’re Jewish’: Liverpool Street station overrun by pro-Palestine protest
    Social media users have reacted online after pro-Palestinian activists took over London's Liverpool Street Station to stage a sit-in protest, calling for an end to Israel's attacks on Gaza. Over 500 pro-Palestinian activists organised a sit-in protest, denouncing the Israel-Hamas conflict. The sit-in, orchestrated by the direct action group Sisters Uncut, featured Palestinian music and chants like "ceasefire now". Various activist groups, including the Palestinian Youth Movement and International Jewish Anti-Zionist Network, joined the demonstration. The protest concluded around 7 p.m. and the station continued its operations, a Network Rail spokeswoman confirmed. British Transport Police responded to reports of the protest and reportedly ensured a safe dispersal of the crowd, allowing passengers access to the station. A similar sit-in involving more than 200 people occurred at London Waterloo station on the preceding Saturday.

  • Open

    Two Bangladeshi opposition activists killed in anti-government protests
    Violence erupted in Bangladesh as opposition activists clashed with police during protests against the government. The protests, initiated by the Bangladesh Nationalist Party (BNP) and Jamaat-e-Islami, called for the resignation of Prime Minister Sheikh Hasina ahead of the upcoming elections. Two BNP members were killed, and over 100 were injured during the clashes. International concerns have been raised, with several countries calling for restraint and a fair election process. The US Ambassador has urged all sides to hold talks, but Prime Minister Hasina has rejected the call.  ( 51 min )
    Two US cities witness biggest Halloween snowfall in over three decades
    Residents of Minneapolis-Saint Paul were surprised by a significant snowfall on Halloween, with over 2.5 inches of snow covering the Twin Cities. This is one of the most substantial snowfalls in decades for the area. The last time a Halloween snowstorm of this magnitude occurred was in 1991. The snowfall ranks among the highest October accumulations for Minnesota. The morning commute was challenging due to icy road conditions, leading to numerous crashes.  ( 44 min )
    France vows 'merciless fight' against antisemitism after anti-Jewish graffiti found in Paris
    French Prime Minister Elisabeth Borne has pledged to "mercilessly fight" against rising anti-Semitism after anti-Jewish graffiti was discovered on buildings in several districts of Paris. Borne emphasized that the situation in the Middle East does not justify anti-Semitism and that her government is determined to combat it. Since the recent Israel-Hamas conflict, French authorities have registered 857 anti-Semitic acts, prompting Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin to open investigations and assure Jewish communities of their protection.  ( 45 min )
    Israel army confirms refugee camp bombing to kill Hamas commander
    The Israel Defence Forces (IDF) claimed to have killed Hamas commander Ibrahim Biari in a strike in the Gaza Strip. Hamas denied his presence in the camp, but IDF said Biari was responsible for sending terrorists to carry out an attack on Israel. The strike targeted Hamas command and control, damaging their ability to direct military activity. Around 50 people were reportedly killed in the strike. IDF spokesperson Rear Admiral Daniel Hagari said the fighting in Gaza is becoming more complex as soldiers operate deeper into the region.  ( 52 min )
    EU's top diplomat Borrell condemns West Bank attacks by Israeli settlers
    The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, has called for a pause in the Israel-Hamas conflict and condemned attacks by Israeli settlers on Palestinians in the occupied West Bank. Borrell expressed concern over the attacks and extended his concerns to related events in the West Bank. Israel has launched raids and air strikes on Gaza, resulting in numerous casualties, and has also increased operations in the West Bank. The Israeli army recently demolished the home of exiled Hamas leader Saleh al-Aruri.  ( 45 min )
    Russia will succeed in Ukraine unless US support continues: Pentagon chief
    US Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned that Russia would be successful in Ukraine without continued US support for Kyiv. Austin made the statement during a testimony to the Senate Appropriations Committee on President Biden's request for $106 billion to fund plans for Ukraine, Israel, and US border security. Biden requested $61.4 billion for Ukraine, with half of the funds to be spent in the US to replenish weapons stocks. Congress has approved $113 billion for Ukraine since Russia's invasion in February 2022.  ( 46 min )
    Explainer: Why US offshore wind industry is in doldrums
    Energy giants BP and Equinor have reported significant impairments on their US offshore wind power portfolios, highlighting the challenges facing the renewable energy industry. Danish company Orsted has also warned of impairments due to supply delays, high-interest rates, and a lack of tax credits. These setbacks raise questions about the future of offshore wind projects in the US, which President Joe Biden has championed as part of his climate change agenda. The industry has faced obstacles including inflation, financing costs, and insufficient subsidies, leading developers to renegotiate contracts or withdraw from projects.  ( 57 min )
    Man kills 2 over noise complaint in New York
    A disturbing incident took place in New York, where a neighbor shot and killed a father and his stepson during an argument over noise. The incident was captured on video, showing the neighbor pacing angrily outside his neighbor's apartment before shooting the victims. The audio was not captured, so the exact conversation between the two is unclear. The neighbor calmly observed the scene before fleeing, but he has been identified by the police. The wife of the victim insists that her husband was not at fault and questions why the neighbor brought a gun to the argument.  ( 49 min )
    Nordic countries to cooperate more on returning migrants to countries of origin
    The Nordic governments, including Denmark, Sweden, Finland, Norway, and Iceland, have announced plans to strengthen their cooperation in returning immigrants without legal residence back to their countries of origin. Denmark's strict immigration policies have drawn criticism, but are now being viewed as a model by other Nordic countries. The governments have agreed to enhance cooperation between diplomatic personnel and arrange joint flights to return illegal residents.  ( 47 min )
    Putin seeking to 'take advantage' of Israel-Hamas war: Antony Blinken
    US secretary of state Antony Blinken accused Russian president Vladimir Putin of using the Israel-Hamas conflict to reduce Western support for Ukraine. Blinken stated that Putin hopes the Hamas attack on Israel will distract the US and result in a withdrawal of resources from Ukraine. Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin warned that without US support, Putin would be successful in seizing Ukrainian territory. The US is the largest donor of military aid to Ukraine.  ( 47 min )
    US Supreme Court weighs if public officials can block critics on social media
    The U.S. Supreme Court is considering cases from California and Michigan to determine whether public officials can legally block critics on social media. Lower courts have reached different conclusions, highlighting the uncertainty around whether such actions are protected by the First Amendment. The justices are tasked with deciding whether the officials were acting in their personal capacity or engaged in "state action." Advocacy groups are urging the court to support the plaintiffs.  ( 57 min )
    Bangladesh: Retired army general arrested over fake 'Biden's adviser' connection
    Former army general Chowdhury Hasan Suhrawardi has been arrested in Bangladesh for allegedly orchestrating a media appearance by a Bangladeshi-American who claimed to be a close advisor to US President Joe Biden. The American, Mian Zahidul Islam Arefy, has been charged with fraudulence and instigating anarchy, and Suhrawardi is accused of being the mastermind behind the scheme. The US embassy in Dhaka has stated that Arefy does not speak for the US government and is a private individual.  ( 50 min )
    Sam Bankman-Fried grilled on 'cozy' relationship with Bahamas officials
    During his fraud trial, FTX founder Sam Bankman-Fried was questioned about his relationship with Bahamian officials. The prosecutor sought to link favors done for the officials with Bankman-Fried's decision to allow FTX customers in the Bahamas to withdraw funds after withdrawals for others had been halted. Bankman-Fried, who is facing charges of fraud and conspiracy, denied offering to pay off the Bahamas' national debt but admitted to offering a job to the son of the Bahamian prime minister. He also stated that he could not recall whether he gave the prime minister and his wife seats at a Miami Heat game.  ( 50 min )
    Biden's Arab American support drops amid Gaza conflict
    A new poll shows that President Joe Biden's support among Arab Americans has dropped significantly, from 59% in 2020 to just 17% now. This decline in support is attributed to growing anger over Biden's support for Israel's attacks on Gaza. The poll also reveals that a majority of Arab Americans no longer identify as Democrats, with 32% identifying as Republicans and 31% as independents. The poll highlights the challenge Biden may face in winning over key Arab American voters.  ( 49 min )
    Rishi Sunak embraces Elon Musk to boost AI summit
    UK Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is hosting a summit on AI safety, aiming to assert Britain's influence and gain an advantage in the technology. While state leaders have been hesitant to attend due to other global conflicts, Elon Musk will bring star power to the event with a live-streamed conversation on his social media platform, X. Sunak hopes to shape a global approach to AI regulation, with the summit serving as a test case for Britain's ability to set its own rules after Brexit.  ( 65 min )

    Russia - Ukraine War News Updates -- October 31, 2023 (Videos)

    Yemens' Houthi Rebels Claim Responsibility For Drones And Missiles Launched Towards Israel's Coastal City Of Eilat
    Daily Mail: Iran boasts its proxies 'won't stay silent' and hints of war across the region as Tehran-backed Huthi rebels fire drones into Israel from Yemen and pledge allegiance to the Hamas 'axis of resistance'  * Houthi rebels said they fired a series of drones towards Israeli city of Eilat  * Iran today warned the situation in the Middle East could 'get out of control'  Iran today boasted its powerful proxies 'won't stay silent' and hinted the fighting between Israel and Hamas could engulf the Middle East after the Tehran-backed Huthi rebels fired drones into the Jewish state from Yemen.  The Huthis, who seized Yemen's capital Sanaa in 2014 and control large swathes of the country, said they fired a series of drones towards the Red Sea city of Eilat this morning in retaliation to Israel's war against Hamas.  'These drones belong to the state of Yemen. We are fighting with words and drones,' Abdelaziz bin Habtour, prime minister of the Huthi government, said.   Read more ....  Yemens' Houthi Rebels Claim Responsibility For Drones And Missiles Launched Towards Israel's Coastal City Of Eilat   Yemen's Houthi rebels claim attacks on Israel, drawing their main sponsor Iran closer to Hamas war -- ABC News/AP In first, Arrow downs Eilat-bound missile from ‘Red Sea area’; Houthis claim attack -- Times of Israel   Israel intercepts 'aerial target' near Red Sea city of Eilat -- Jerusalem Post   Israel uses ‘Arrow’ aerial defense system for first time in war to intercept missile -- Al Arabiya News   Yemeni army launches large-scale ballistic, drone strikes on occupied territories to support Palestinians -- Press TV (Iran)   Yemen’s Houthis say they launched ballistic missiles, drones at Israel -- Al Jazeera   Israel-Gaza Situation Report: Arrow Interceptor Downs Ballistic Missile Over Red Sea -- The Warzone
    Are The U.S. Administration's Bills On Israel, Ukraine Aid 'Dead On Arrival' In Both House And Senate?
    🚨What every American should know about Biden's $105B aid package- It leverages the attacks against Israel to send BILLONS more to Ukraine, slows down Israel from getting the help they need in their time of war, does nothing to actually secure our borders, & is DOA in the House. pic.twitter.com/Ytf3V4mhMS — Dr. Roger Marshall (@RogerMarshallMD) October 28, 2023 Zero Hedge: Bills On Israel, Ukraine 'Dead On Arrival' In Both House And Senate As Shutdown, Funding Battles Gear Up  As the nation celebrates Halloween, the House and Senate are engaged in some spooky late-stage Republic chaos over aid to Israel and Ukraine amid a backdrop of yet another government shutdown looming in two weeks.  * The government will run out of money (again) in roughly two weeks, requiring Congress to act (again).  * According to Democrats and GOP Neocons such as Mitch McConnell and Lindsey Graham, America needs to send billions of taxpayer funds to both Israel and Ukraine, and won't consider any legislation that doesn't combine the two.  * House Republicans under newly minted Speaker Mike Johnson (R-LA), as well as a group of Senate Republicans, want Israel aid separated from Ukraine aid, while the Biden White House wants to jam a $105 billion foreign aid package ($14B to Israel, $60B to Ukraine) through Congress.  * The House's plan (if they can even pass it) to separate Israel aid from Ukraine aid is DOA in the Senate, while both the Senate's combined package and the Biden admin's package is DOA in the House.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: I am confident that both the House and Senate will come to an agreement on this aid. But it is going to take time.
    Secretaries Blinken & Austin Testify On $100B National Security Funding Request For Israel And Ukraine
    The Hill: Blinken, Austin testify on $100B national security funding request  Secretary of State Antony Blinken and Defense Secretary Lloyd Austin are slated to testify Tuesday morning in a hearing before the Senate Appropriations Committee, regarding the Biden administration’s more than $100 billion emergency aid request for conflicts in Israel and Ukraine.  The majority of Democrats and many Republican senators support tying aid for the two countries together.  But, the aid request faces much deeper problems in the Republican-led House, where new Speaker Mike Johnson has proposed cutting out the Ukraine aid and focusing on Israel alone. He’s also proposed cutting money for the Internal Revenue Service (IRS) to pay for it, as The Associated Press reported.   Read more ....   WNU Editor: There were a number of protests during the hearing (see video below).

    U.S. Marine Gen. Eric M.     UN Says A Record 6.9 Million People Are Internally Displaced In DR Congo
    ‼️ Record High Displacement in #DRCongo More people than ever before, nearly 7 million, are internally displaced. Amid growing displacement and increased violence, humanitarian needs are soaring. More in our latest press release 👇https://t.co/oF7KmqrkaN pic.twitter.com/eN3UZk8PJJ — IOM - UN Migration 🇺🇳 (@UNmigration) October 30, 2023 France 24: A record 6.9 million people are internally displaced in DR Congo, says UN  Escalating violence has pushed the number of people internally displaced within the Democratic Republic of Congo to a record 6.9 million, the United Nations said Monday.  The conflict between M23 rebels and militias loyal to the DRC's government has intensified in the eastern province of North Kivu since early October, particularly north of the provincial capital Goma.  The UN's International Organization for Migration said many people who have fled their homes but stayed within the DRC's borders desperately needed help to meet their basic needs.   Read more ....   Update: UN says record 6.9 million people internally displaced in the DR Congo (Africa News)   WNU Editor: Quoting The UN's International Organization for Migration (IOM) .... "With ongoing conflict and escalating violence, the DRC is facing one of the largest internal displacement and humanitarian crises in the world."

    Can Creativity Change the World?
    MILAN, Italy, Oct 31 (IPS) - It all fits into an off-road vehicle that can reach even the most remote parts of Southern Africa to bring cinema where the essentials are lacking, where there's no electricity to power a projector, and where perhaps no one has ever sat in front of a screen to watch a movie. With just the sun and a solar panel, a theater can be set up in areas where people struggle to access food and water and make a decent living. But what it truly requires is the courage to not view creativity as a luxury. Sydelle and Rowand, the founders of Sunshine Cinema, a network of mobile movie theaters, are not just entertaining people; they are crossing a bridge. Read the full story, “Can Creativity Change the World?”, on globalissues.org →  ( 6 min )
    Women Correct Historical Injustices, Build Climate Resilience Through Cash Pooling
    NAIROBI, Oct 31 (IPS) - Excluded by inheritance and ignored by big business, women farmers in Kenya are turning to innovative methods to become independent food producers and get the financial backing to ensure their success. Creating resilience is crucial to adapting to climate change and ensuring climate justice.  Although women account for more than three-quarters of the agricultural labour force and manage 40 percent of small-scale farms, historically, they neither owned nor controlled the land because land rights were passed down to male relatives. It is a historic gender injustice whereby women could only access land through close male relatives. Read the full story, “Women Correct Historical Injustices, Build Climate Resilience Through Cash Pooling”, on globalissues.org →  ( 6 min )

    Women and War
    STOCKHOLM, Sweden, Oct 31 (IPS) - In 1968, the tobacco company Philip Morris introduced a new cigarette brand called Virginia Slims. Under the slogan “You’ve come a long way, baby” it was exclusively marketed to women. The advertising campaign exploited the civil rights movements of the 1960s, indicating that those cigarettes were enjoyed by strong, independent, and liberated women. A blatant lie – why would “independent” women choose to poison themselves with a commodity which each year causes more than 480,000 deaths in the US alone – nearly one in five deaths? Another question arising from this deceitful ad is: “How far have women come on their way to independence and liberation?” Read the full story, “Women and War”, on globalissues.org →  ( 8 min )

    10 years ago, we were turning nuclear bombs into nuclear energy. We can do it again.
    Getty Images How we turned 20,000 Soviet nukes into zero-carbon energy — and how we can do the same with some of our own. Just a decade ago, one in 10 American lightbulbs was powered by dismantled Russian nuclear weapons. That was made possible by the Megatons to Megawatts program, an agreement negotiated after the collapse of the Soviet Union to convert uranium from Russia’s nuclear weapons stockpile into fuel for US nuclear power plants. The unconventional policy was first proposed by MIT physicist Thomas Neff in a 1991 New York Times op-ed. By the time Megatons to Megawatts ran its full course from 1993 to 2013, it had eliminated about 20,000 nuclear warheads and stood out as a point of shared pride in the often jaded arms control and disarmament field. “Nearly every commercia…  ( 15 min )
